Posts.Content: Feb 25, 2009 05:27PM mmliv wrote: Regarding skin issues - my rad onc said that creams and lotions will not prevent a rash. Some people (about 30%) will get a rash whether or not they use creams. He said if a cream was soothing.... then that was the cream to use for our own comfort. Regarding positioning - the rad onc showed my DH and me how the x-ray imagaing matches the CT scan when we are positioned properly. That is why they X-ray us prior to the treatment; once they are convinced that the positioning will always be good then they may not x-ray every time.  I had my 6th session today (9 more to go) and have very few effects; sometimes a little tenderness, but I am still wearing my normal bra. I have not used any lotions or creams and do not notice any skin difference between the two breasts. I am still recovering from chemo, but my diminishing of chemo SEs must be more than the increasing fatigue of radiation..... Recently I am feeling more energetic every day. The last two weeks were tiring for me (maybe a combination of post nasal drip and cold weather) and so I am delighted to be feeling better. That said, I do need my sleep at night and do nap; because we have a small business I have tremendous flexibility on when I do "my part". Mary L

They would do the "quick" test during surgery and if appeared cancer free, then only do a lumpectomy; but the nodes would be sent out for more accurate testing and if showed cancer then additional surgery would be needed. Still achy, but it is better.  Now am beginning to be worried about WBC levels - I've had no shot. What are you other ladies doing to ensure no infection? Mary

Can someone please tell me whatpasties are?  Cebula - don't feel bad, not many people know of them. I've met some Montana people that have them in their area..... but that is it. Pasties (and I am referring to Cornish pasties) are made with an 8 oz mixture of ground round, onion, potatoes, and seasoning; then wrapped in a type of pie dough. It then can be eaten like a turnover. Many people also like to add rutabaga, carrots, substitute chicken, etc .... but I don't like those combinations as well. I'll let the other Yoopers give their favorite ingredients..... maybe we can make this a recipe forum as well!!!! LOL with our taste buds....... HAH! Posts.Content: Jan 15, 2009 08:11AM mmliv wrote: Day 3 after TC #3 - Other than being a bit more tired, I actually feel pretty good. I was asking the onc nurse about trying to diminish the fatigue that I get on days 4 and 5 and she said it was due to a low red blood cell count. I then asked if eating iron rich foods would help..... she said probably not; but since I am trying to eat healthful foods.... I am ensuring that I am getting good sources of iron. Dry skin - Lotion, lotion, lotion! Though I bought some brands that were recommended, I discovered they did have alcohol. Anybody else noticing strength issues? I'm going to start an upper body workout now to my fitness routine. I am going to have to look up Zumba! Hormone therapy - I am scheduled to go on Femara. I will just wait and see what the SEs are. My cancer likes estrogen and it is also an aggressive type... so I am going at it full bore! Carie -  did your DH make it to you?
